did.physloc: To access physical materials at the Getty, go to the library catalog record for this collection and click "Request an Item." Click here for general library access policy. See the Administrative Information section of this finding aid for access restrictions specific to the records described below. Please note, some of the records may be stored off site; advanced notice is required for access to these materials.
did.abstract: The collection consists of digitized and analog audio recordings, video recordings, and photographs of the people and events related to the Scholars Program at the Getty Research Institute. The materials date 1985-2013 and include recordings and photographs of lectures, panel discussions, conferences, and other events hosted by the Getty Research Institute and given by Getty Scholars, staff, and invited speakers. The collection also includes portraits of the program scholars and photo releases signed by scholars.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Restricted materials have been removed from this collection and returned to the department that created them.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: Initial physical processing and inventory of 1996.IA.02 performed by Daniel Feser. Project completed by Rebecca Fenning, November 2006.
Additional processing and inventory of 1995.IA.02 performed and completed by Kyle Morgan, November 2008.
Additional processing and inventory of 2006.IA.24 performed and completed by Kyle Morgan, May 2010.

In 2010 and 2011 Cyndi Shein and Annie Tang edited and reformatted digital versions of the audio recordings, restructured Series II, and enhanced the descriptive and administrative metadata related to the audio recordings. In 2011 Zoe MacLeod edited and reformatted some of the audio recordings.
In 2011 and 2012 Tim Chang edited and reformatted digital versions of the audio recordings and enhanced the descriptive metadata.

From 2011 to 2013 Simon Yu and Cyndi Shein reformatted digital versions of the audio recordings, enhanced the descriptive metadata, and created administrative and technical metadata related to the audio recordings.
Additional processing and inventory of 2019.IA.31 performed and completed by Helen Kim, May 2019.
In 2020, Helen Kim and Lorain Wang processed digitized audio recordings from 1996.IA.02 and ingested them to the digital preservation repository.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The records in this finding aid originated from the following accessions: 1987.IA.26, 1994.IA.02, 1995.IA.02, 1996.IA.02, 1997.IA.01, 2006.IA.24, 2009.IA.41, and 2019.IA.31.

prefercite.p: [Cite the item and series (as appropriate)], Scholars Program images and recordings, 1985-2013, Getty Research Institute. The Getty Research Institute (IA20026).

phystech.head: Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Use copies do not exist for all audio or video recordings in this collection. The production of use copies is required before access can be granted and may add a delay to research requests. Special handling and gloves are required for the handling of contact prints and negatives.
Access to digital files is available online through the links provided in the inventory. Due to rights restrictions, some online recordings are available to on-site researchers only.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Contact Library Rights and Reproductions at the Getty Research Institute for copyright information and permission to publish.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The records described in accession 1987.IA.26, 1994.IA.02, 1995.IA.02, 1996.IA.02, 1997.IA.01, 2009.IA.41, and 2006.IA.24 are available for use by qualified researchers. Accession 2019.IA.31 is restricted to staff only.

Some materials are digitized and accessible online. Master recordings are restricted; use copies or online digital copies exist for most of the recordings. Absence of use copies is noted at the file level in this finding aid. Where use copies do not exist, production of use copies is required before access will be granted; this may delay research requests. Advanced notice is required. Some recordings are restricted to on-site use only or are not available at all at the request of the participants.

The following types of records are permanently closed: records containing personal information, records that compromise security or operations, legal communications, legal work product, and records related to donors. The J. Paul Getty Trust reserves the right to restrict access to any records held by the Institutional Archives.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The collection comprises audio recordings, video recordings, and photographs of the people and events related to the Getty Research Institute Scholars Program and its predecessors, dating from 1985 to 2013.

The audiovisual recordings primarily comprise audiocassette and compact disc recordings of lectures, panel discussions, conferences, and other events hosted by the Getty Research Institute and given by Getty Scholars, staff, and invited speakers, dating from 1987 to 2001. Many of the recordings have been digitized. The lectures and events hosted by the Scholars Program tend to focus on the given theme for that particular scholar year. Other symposia and conferences represented in this collection cover various topics, and, although held at a Getty facility and attended by Getty Scholars, may not have been hosted by the Scholars Program. Also included are video tapes of a symposium on Florentine patronage (1986-1987) and a viewing schedule covering the research theme of the Getty Scholars Program for the 1986/1987 year: "Seventeenth Century Dutch Art and Society/Patronage."

The images principally comprise portraits of scholars from 1985 to 2007, contact sheets, negatives, and oversize photograph prints (8"x10" and 11"x14"). The photographs were primarily used to select official scholar portraits, but they also document to a lesser extent the outings, events, and lectures that Getty Scholars attended.
The collection also includes restricted photo releases signed by scholars from 1997 to 2013.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The materials are arranged into four series. Please note that Series III and IV are available for staff use only.
Series I. Audio recordings, 1987-2001;
Series II. Video recordings, 1986-1987;
Series III. Photographs, 1985-2007 (restricted) and
Series IV. Photo Releases, 1997-2013 (restricted).

bioghist.head: Administrative History
bioghist.p: The Getty Research Institute (GRI) is a program developed and overseen by the J. Paul Getty Trust, an international cultural and philanthropic organization serving both general audiences and specialized professionals. The Trust is a not-for-profit institution, educational in purpose and character that focuses on the visual arts in all of their dimensions. The Trust currently supports and oversees four programs: the J. Paul Getty Museum; the Getty Foundation; the Getty Conservation Institute; and the Getty Research Institute (GRI).

Located at the Getty Center in the Brentwood neighborhood of Los Angeles, California, the GRI creates and disseminates new knowledge through its expertise, its active collecting program, public programs, institutional collaborations, exhibitions, publications, digital services, and residential scholars program. The GRI also provides intellectual leadership through its research projects and its innovative digital reference tools. The GRI's Research Library, consisting of over one million books, periodicals, study photographs, auction catalogs and special collections of rare and unique materials, serve an international community of scholars and the interested public. The activities and scholarly resources of the GRI guide and sustain each other and, together, provide a unique environment for research, critical inquiry, and debate.
The origins of the J. Paul Getty Trust date to 1953, when J. Paul Getty established the J. Paul Getty Museum as a California charitable trust to house his growing art collections. Originally a small, private institution located in Mr. Getty's Ranch House near Malibu, California, the museum moved to the newly constructed Getty Villa on grounds adjacent to the Ranch House in 1974. When most of Mr. Getty's personal estate passed to the Trust in 1982, the Trustees decided that, given the size of the endowment, it should make a greater contribution to the visual arts and humanities than the museum could alone.

The establishment of an arts library had already been proposed as early as 1977 by then Museum Director Stephen Garrett, when in February 1982, Trust President Harold Williams' chief deputy Nancy Englander outlined a proposed "Center for Advanced Study." This proposed center would include a residence program for scholars, a major expansion of the library, a limited publications program, and an art photo archive. The center would focus on the preservation of historic art history materials and the development of new art history reference tools using state-of-the-art information technology. The plan was approved and the Getty Center for the History of the Arts and the Humanities (GCHAH) opened in temporary quarters in the First Federal Building at 401 Wilshire Boulevard, Santa Monica, in July 1983. In 1996, in order to avoid confusion with the soon-to-open Getty Center in Brentwood, the GCHAH was renamed the Getty Research Institute for the History of Art and the Humanities. In 2000, the program's name was shortened to the GRI.

Noted architectural historian Kurt Forster began work as the first director of the GCHAH in the fall of 1984. One of the original departments in the GCHAH was the Visiting Scholars and Conferences department, headed by Herb Hymans, and it was this department that inaugurated the Scholars Program in the fall of 1985, inviting 17 scholars and fellows to explore the theme "Aesthetic Experience and Affinities Among the Arts." Since that first year, the number of scholars has fluctuated between 20 and 30, but the treatment and consideration of a specific theme has remained a constant.

In addition to hosting the Scholars Program, the Visiting Scholars and Conferences department was also responsible for organizing scholarly activities, events, and conferences. The department went through several name changes and restructuring in the years that followed. In the mid-1990s, it was renamed the Scholars and Seminars Program and later renamed the Scholars and Conferences Department. In 1998, its activities were encompassed in the new Department of Research and Education, which included the development of new art historical scholarship and to consolidate programming activities. As a result of the GRI reorganization in 2009, the department was split into two: a new department, Research Projects and Programs, and the Scholars Program dedicated to scholar activities. As of 2009, the Scholars Program reports directly to the Director of the GRI.

odd.head: Additional Information Available
odd.p: Additional information regarding Getty Scholar years, themes, and participants can be accessed on the Getty site at: http://hdl.handle.net/10020/grischolarsprogram.

Please note that scholar event recordings created from Scholar Year 2001/2002 through the present are not listed in this inventory. Lists of recordings from 2001/2002 and following are part of broader collections and are available through the following inventories:
The Getty Research Institute Public Event Recordings (for events related to modern and contemporary topics that were held at the GRI);
The Getty Villa Event Recordings (for events related to ancient cultures and antiquities that were held at the Getty Villa).

Most of the public Getty Scholar recordings from 2001/2002 forward have also been described individually. For additional information on a particular event, search the Getty Research Institute Library Catalog by event name or participant name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The material consists of audiocassette and compact disc recordings of lectures, panel discussions, conferences, and other events hosted by the Getty Research Institute (and its predecessors) and given by Getty Scholars, staff, and invited speakers, 1987-2001. Every year since 1985 the Research Institute has invited scholars, artists, and other cultural figures from around the world to work in residence at the Institute on projects that bear upon its annual research theme. While in residence, they pursue their own research projects, make use of Getty collections, and participate in the intellectual life of the Getty Center and the Getty Villa.The lectures and events hosted by the Scholars Program tend to focus on the given theme for that particular scholar year (see Past Themes and Scholars in Residence for a list of past scholars and scholar year themes). Other lectures and events represented in this collection, although held at the Getty Center and attended by Getty Scholars, were not specifically hosted by the Scholars Program and cover varied topics. These include ongoing series such as Works-in-Progress as well as special symposia and conferences held at the Getty Center.

odd.head: Additional Information Available
odd.p: Please note that scholar event recordings created from Scholar Year 2001/2002 through the present are not listed in this inventory. Lists of recordings from 2001/2002 and following are part of broader collections and are available through the following inventories:
The Getty Research Institute Public Event Recordings (for events related to modern and contemporary topics that were held at the GRI);
The Getty Villa Event Recordings (for events related to ancient cultures and antiquities that were held at the Getty Villa).

Most of the public Getty Scholar recordings from 2001/2002 forward have also been described individually. For additional information on a particular event, search the Getty Research Institute Library Catalog by event name or participant name.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Access to digital files is available online through the links provided in the inventory. Due to rights restrictions, some online recordings are available to on-site researchers only.
The quality of the recordings varies. Audience members are often difficult to hear during discussions / question and answer sessions. Incomplete recordings are noted when known.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Institutional Archives is in the process of creating access copies of the audio recordings. Online versions of the audio recordings have been created for scholar year 1986/1987 through 2000/2001. Online versions of the recordings are available to on-site researchers only. A researcher may request access of recordings available for on-site access only by placing a request through the Getty's Interlibrary Loan program.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials comprise recordings of events, lectures, and discussions held at the Getty during the scholar year 1986/1987. During this time Getty Scholars explored two research themes: Seventeenth Century Dutch painting and the broader issues of art patronage. The scholars were drawn from disciplines ranging from art history to economic history. While most of the lectures given during this academic year were inspired by the scholar theme "Seventeenth Century Dutch Art and Society/Patronage," some of the lectures are not thematically related.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Due to rights restrictions, online versions of the recordings are available to on-site researchers only. A researcher may request use copies (CDs) of specific recordings for in-library use at a local library by placing a request through the Getty's Interlibrary Loan program.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials comprise recordings of events, lectures, and discussions held at the Getty during the scholar year 1987/1988. During this time Getty Scholars pursued individual areas of research while also exploring the theme of reception and interpretation of works of art and cultural products. Scholars approached this theme from their personal areas of expertise, which ranged from photography through ethnomathematics. While many of the lectures given during this academic year were inspired by the scholar theme: "Reception and Interpretation of the Arts," some of the recordings are not thematically related.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials comprise recordings of events, lectures, and discussions held at the Getty during the scholar year 1988/1989. During this time Getty Scholars focused on the distinctive qualities of cultural products selected for historical analysis or the ways in which scholarly interpretations are linked to particular methodological and theoretical assumptions. Many stressed close observation of cultural customs, traditions, and patterns of production. Others examined disciplinary practices and their interpretive strategies. Vital contributions were made toward fashioning interdisciplinary approaches for analyzing cultural continuities and changes. This group of scholars was drawn from the fields of anthropology, ethnography, the history of art, social history, and sociology. While many of the lectures given during this academic year were inspired by the scholar theme "The Production of Artifacts and the Formation of Disciplines," some of the lectures are not thematically related.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The recordings are grouped first by symposia/theme, followed by a group of more general lectures and presentations. Within each group, the recordings are in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials comprise recordings of events, lectures, and discussions held at the Getty during the scholar year 1989/1990. During this year the Getty Scholars played an important role in the development of a more comprehensive and interdisciplinary approach to the arts of the early twentieth century, especially those called avant-garde, by increasing our understanding of the cultures in which they flourished. The fields of interest represented included comparative literature, the history of art and architecture, musicology, psychology, and film history. While most of the lectures given during this academic year were inspired by the scholar theme "The Avant-Garde," some of the lectures are not thematically related.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials comprise recordings of events, lectures, and discussions held at the Getty during the scholar year 1990/1991. This scholar year was originally centered around classical antiquity. A broad spectrum of scholars working in that field were invited, together with a smaller satellite group working on the Ancient Near East, Africa, Pre-Columbian America, and Asia. The group of scholars who accepted the invitation engaged in a rich comparativist interplay related to their studies in Pre-Columbian and colonial Peru, Africa, the Ancient Near East, Etruscan Italy, and the Hellenistic world. In the end, only Asia was unrepresented. While most of the lectures given during this academic year were inspired by the scholar theme "Time and Ritual in Antiquity," some of the lectures are not thematically related.

dao.xlink:title: Scholar Year 1990-1991: Anyone Conference audio recordings

daodesc.p: Scholar Year 1990-1991: Anyone Conference audio recordings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Anyone Conference was held at the University of California, Los Angeles. This conference was the first in a series of Any conferences, which took place in the decade leading up to the year 2000. Multidisciplinary and cross-cultural in nature, the "Any" conferences focused on the condition of architecture at the end of the millennium. Participants in the 1991 conference included Akira Asada, Francesco Dal Co, Jacques Derrida, Peter Eisenman, William Gibson, Arata Isozaki, Fredric Jameson, Kojin Karatani, Jeffrey Kipnis, Rem Koolhaas, Rosalind Krauss, Rafael Moneo, John Rajchman, Ignasi de Solà-Morales Rubió, David Salle, R.E. Somol, Mark C. Taylor, Roberto Mangabeira Unger, and Anthony Vidler. Materials comprise master audiocassettes, as well as copies.

Lectures that were conducted at the conference, but of which audio files were not found, include: Ignasi de Solà-Morales Rubió: "From Autonomy to Untimeliness"; Frank Gehry: "Hook, Line, and Signature"; Maria Nordman: "Infinite Openness"; and Daniel Libeskind: "ANYONE? A Text for a Ventriloquist."
Additional information can be found at http://www.anycorp.com/any_conferences.php
Several lectures are incomplete due to missing cassette recordings or inadvertent loss during the transfer process from cassette tapes to computer audio files.

dao.xlink:title: Scholar Year 1990/1991: Lectures and presentations audio recordings

daodesc.p: Scholar Year 1990/1991: Lectures and presentations audio recordings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials comprise recordings of events, lectures, and discussions held at the Getty during the scholar year 1990/1991. This scholar year was originally centered around classical antiquity. A broad spectrum of scholars working in that field were invited, together with a smaller satellite group working on the Ancient Near East, Africa, Pre-Columbian America, and Asia. The group of scholars who accepted the invitation engaged in a rich comparativist interplay related to their studies in Pre-Columbian and colonial Peru, Africa, the Ancient Near East, Etruscan Italy, and the Hellenistic world. In the end, only Asia was unrepresented. While most of the lectures given during this academic year were inspired by the scholar theme "Time and Ritual in Antiquity," some of the lectures are not thematically related.

dao.xlink:title: Scholar Year 1991/1992 audio recordings

daodesc.p: Scholar Year 1991/1992 audio recordings

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The recordings are grouped first by symposia/theme, followed by a group of more general lectures and presentations. Within each group, the recordings are in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials comprise recordings of events, lectures, and discussions held at the Getty during the scholar year 1991/1992. The theme for the year was "Popular and Mass Culture." During this time scholars engaged in research of the realms of expression variously labeled traditional, popular, folk, ethnic, and commercial. Research focused on the nature and impact of popular and traditional beliefs on religion, education, imagery, and culture from the Middle Ages to the present. The fields of study represented included art, architecture, dance, literature, philosophy, and film.

From March to June of 1992, selected events were conducted under Thomas Reese's project, Shifting Boundaries/Contested Space, a collection of presentations based on popular culture, the overall theme for that year. Several panels, series, and conferences are included for the 1991-1992 scholar year, and of those that were explicitly stated in the recordings to be part of the project, their inclusion is stated in a note.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: A researcher may request access of recordings available for on-site access only by placing a request through the Getty's Interlibrary Loan program.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials comprise recordings of events, lectures, and discussions held at the Getty during the scholar year 1991/1992 that were not part of specific symposia or conferences. The theme for the year was "Popular and Mass Culture." During this time scholars engaged in research of expression variously labeled traditional, popular, folk, ethnic, and commercial. They explored the thresholds between these categories. Research focused on the nature and impact of popular and traditional beliefs on religion, education, imagery, and culture from the Middle Ages to the present. The fields of study represented included art, architecture, dance, literature, philosophy, and film.

Some of the recordings in this section were part of larger group of lectures under a project headed by Thomas Reese and David Jensen, the Shifting Boundaries/Contested Space series (a group of presentations based on popular culture). The relationship between the recording and the series has been noted where known, but it is possible that not all of the recordings in the series have been identified.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials comprise recordings of events, lectures, and discussions held at the Getty during the scholar year 1992/1993. The theme for the year was "The Metropolis as Crucible." The Getty invited scholars to explore the metropolitan experience and its impact on culture in its many social, literary, industrial, and visual aspects. The fields of study represented included art, architecture, ethnic studies, literature, philosophy and film.

scopecontent.p: Materials comprise audio recordings of discussions and lectures related to the performance, "Perspectives on LA at the Jodo Shu Betsuin Buddhist Temple," which was part of a series of public programs in downtown Los Angeles that coincided with the Getty/ CalArts joint conference on "The Aesthetics of Community-Based Art Making." The intent of the event was to discuss issues raised by the arts with respect to culture, identity, democracy, and education, while considering the arts as an agent of cultural change. This event was part of the Getty Scholar Year 1992/1993, which was themed "The Metropolis as Crucible."

unittitle.emph: Sexual Illegals, Barbershop Soundscape, Hittite Empire,

dao.xlink:title: (1996.IA.01_1996.IA.02) Scholar Year 1993/1994: Sexual Illegals, Barbershop Soundscape, Hittite Empire audio recordings

daodesc.p: (1996.IA.01_1996.IA.02) Scholar Year 1993/1994: Sexual Illegals, Barbershop Soundscape, Hittite Empire audio recordings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials comprise audio recordings of an event held at the Getty during the scholar year 1993/1994 under the theme "The Americas." The recordings capture African American male poets/writers each telling a "story" or reciting a poem about an experience from their own lives and discussing why that memory is meaningful to them. Following individual readings is a discussion between writer-director Keith Antar Mason, professional barbers, and participating poets revealing the barbershop as central to African American culture--a place where men experience symbolic rites of passage and bond as they share experiences, folklore, and milestones in their lives.

The Getty documented the Hittite Empire theater troupe's process of connecting the oral history tradition transposed from Africa to L.A.'s urban barbershops. Keith Antar Mason's research on barbershops was the basis for a theater piece, "Sexual Illegals," performed by the Hittite Empire, which was one of five Memory Projects commissioned as part of the 1993 L.A. Festival. The recordings herein are related to this performance, but do not document it.

The complete series took place in August and September of 1993 and was co-sponsored by the Getty, the Los Angeles Festival, and the Lannan Foundation.

dao.xlink:title: Scholar Year 1993/1994: Power and Responsibility audio recordings

daodesc.p: Scholar Year 1993/1994: Power and Responsibility audio recordings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials comprise 1993 audio recordings of a symposium that explored questions about the nature of museums, their origins, their authority to "speak" on behalf of the populace, and the relationship of these issues to concepts of power. Issues are addressed from different perspectives influenced by various social, economic, and political conditions.

Participants included an international group of arts administrators, artists, curators, and critics who discuss issues of access to cultural decision-making, relationships between public and private spheres, questions of audience and community, and ethical concerns about the control of distribution of works of art, images, and ideas.

Panelists included David Avalos, visual artist, Los Angeles; Marie Claude-Beaud, Cartier Foundation, France; Olivier Debroise, novelist and culture critic, Mexico; Tom Finkelpearl, Public Arts Program, New York; Felix Gonzalez-Torres, artist, Group Material USA, New York; Vasif Kortun, curator, Istanbul; James Luna, artist, La Jolla Reservation, California; Declan McGonagle, Museum Director, Dublin, and others.
The symposium was planned jointly by the Getty, the California Institute for the Arts, and the Museum of Contemporary Art.

unittitle.emph: Cine City: Film and Perceptions of Urban Space, 1895-1995,

dao.xlink:title: Scholar Year 1993/1994: Cine City: Film and Perceptions of Urban Space from 1895-1995, audio recordings

daodesc.p: Scholar Year 1993/1994: Cine City: Film and Perceptions of Urban Space from 1895-1995, audio recordings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials comprise audio recordings of lectures from "Cine City: Film and Perceptions of Urban Space, 1895-1995," a symposium that explored film's role in visualizing the future and how architecture has affected the evolution of film. The five-day international symposium brought together architects, filmmakers, production designers, and architecture and film historians to examine the city as represented in film and its relationship to built form. The symposium was held in 1994 in conjunction with a two-week series of film screenings organized by the Getty that included documentaries, feature films, and experimental films.

unittitle.emph: Imaging the City in the Americas: The Formation and Display of Urban Identity around 1910

dao.xlink:title: Scholar Year 1993/1994: Imaging the City in the Americas: The Formation and Display of Urban Identity around 1910, audio recordings

daodesc.p: Scholar Year 1993/1994: Imaging the City in the Americas: The Formation and Display of Urban Identity around 1910, audio recordings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials comprise 1994 audio recordings of seminars that launched a continued lecture series, "Imaging the City in the Americas. . ." The prototypical seminar was developed by GRI Deputy Director Thomas Reese and a Getty research group that included Claudia Bohn-Spector, Research Project Analyst; Wim De Wit, Head of Special Collections; Margarita Gutman, Getty Scholar, 1993-1994; and Carol McMichael Reese, Scholar Associate. According to Reese, "the research focus of the seminar [was] to consider how the image of the American city came into being and how it functioned in the construction of civic identities. In a multidisciplinary and comparative approach to the subject, and within the context of social, political, and economic conditions of urbanization, the seminar [focused] on selected cities that experienced rapid demographic change and economic expansion in the early 20th century, in order to examine the relationship between the politics of their development and their visual representation in popular culture, art, and literature. The objective [was] to illuminate not only the means by which ideas and images of urban form were constructed for, as well as by, various urban constituencies, but also the full range of modernist technologies that were harnessed for these purposes. Initial seminar sessions focused on Mexico City, Buenos Aires, and Los Angeles."

dao.xlink:title: Scholar Year 1993/1994: Fifteenth-Century Flemish Portraiture audio recordings

daodesc.p: Scholar Year 1993/1994: Fifteenth-Century Flemish Portraiture audio recordings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials comprise audio recordings of a series of instructional lectures presented by art historian Linda Seidel during the scholar year 1993/1994. These five lectures, although hosted by the Getty, were thematically unrelated to other events that year; they were part of a graduate seminar taught by Professor Seidel at UCLA. The lectures focus on Flemish portraiture in the 15th century with significant attention paid to the Arnolfini Wedding Portrait, Ghent Altarpiece, and Freidsam Annunciation by Jan Van Eyck. Lectures touch on work by Robert Campin, Willem van Haecht, and many others. Seidel also discusses Erwin Panofsky's book Early Netherlandish Painting, explores relationships between the writings of Pliny and Flemish painting, and talks about the influences of the culture and religion of the 15th century upon the paintings of the time.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials comprise recordings of events, lectures, and discussions held at the Getty during the scholar year 1994/1995, which was themed "Memory." The GRI extended invitations to a broad range of scholars whose work explored the subject of memory as a psychological, cultural, and historical practice. A particular focus of study was the modes in which memory is organized, whether oral, corporeal, or institutional.

Reese, the "research focus of the seminar is to consider how the image of the American city came into being and how it functioned in the construction of civic identities. In a multidisciplinary and comparative approach to the subject, and within the context of social, political, and economic conditions of urbanization, the seminar focuses on selected cities that experienced rapid demographic change and economic expansion in the early 20th century, in order to examine the relationship between the politics of their development and their visual representation in popular culture, art, and literature. The objective is to illuminate not only the means by which ideas and images of urban form were constructed for, as well as by, various urban constituencies, but also the full range of modernist technologies that were harnessed for these purposes."

unittitle.emph: Imaging the Us: An Exploration of Autobiographical Writings

dao.xlink:title: Scholar Year 1994/1995: Imaging the Us: An Exploration of Autobiographical Writings audio recordings

daodesc.p: Scholar Year 1994/1995: Imaging the Us: An Exploration of Autobiographical Writings audio recordings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials comprise recordings of a series of readings, interviews, and discussions based on the theme, "Imaging the Us." Some of the events in the series were held at the Los Angeles Central Library in April of 1995 and included participants Quincy Troupe, Dorothy Allison, Isaac Julien, Gioconda Belli, Anchee Min, and Greg Sarris, who read from their own autobiographical works and discussed the relationships among autobiographical writing, memory, and the articulation of an "Us." The second aspect of the series was a sequence of radio interviews/discussions with authors hosted by Michael Silverblatt on KCRW. This series of radio interviews, a collaboration between Bookworm and the Getty Center for the History of Art and the Humanities, centered around autobiography and collective memory within the "Imaging the Us" theme.

dao.xlink:title: Scholar Year 1994/1995: Ginzburg, Carlo. "Making Things Strange: The Prehistory of a Literary Device" audio recordings

daodesc.p: Scholar Year 1994/1995: Ginzburg, Carlo. "Making Things Strange: The Prehistory of a Literary Device" audio recordings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The audio recordings capture lectures presented by Carlo Ginzburg in the spring of 1995 as he discusses the concept of "Making Things Strange." Ginzburg suggests that gaining perspective on some works of art is best achieved by distancing oneself from the work, and that this type of estrangement is a literary device with its own unique history.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials comprise recordings of events, lectures, and discussions held at the Getty during the scholar year 1995/1996. During this time Getty scholars explored the theme "The Nature and Idea of Collecting" as a topic broadly defined to include: the social and institutional practice of collecting; how it reflects the values of a given community, region, and era; systems of display and classification; and the emergence of new languages and classes of collecting. Among the areas studied by this year's Getty Scholars were the collecting practices of Renaissance Italy, the dispersal of the art collections of Great Britain after the Civil Wars of 1640, and the social function of collecting in Oceanic cultures.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Artists, writers, curators, scholars, and activists from the United States and Canada explored contemporary Native American cultural issues during a week-long series of programs presented by the Getty Center for the History of Art and the Humanities. Through discussion and performance, the participants exchanged ideas, strategies, stories, and histories that mapped the changing cultural topographies of indigenous North America.

dao.xlink:title: Scholar Year 1996/1997 audio recordings

daodesc.p: Scholar Year 1996/1997 audio recordings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials comprise audio recordings of events, lectures, and discussions held at the Getty during the scholar year 1996/1997. During this time Getty scholars explored the theme Perspectives on Los Angeles: Narratives, Images, History, which was devoted to research on Los Angeles and to comparative projects that viewed the city in relationship to other hemispheric and global sites. Scholars in residence had the opportunity to participate in a number of corollary programs developed by the Research Institute on issues of identity, community, and public culture, as well as programs having to do with preservation, resource development, and the comparative study of cities in the Americas at the turn of the century. A series of lectures was also presented in anticipation of the J. Paul Getty Museum's 1999 exhibition "Dosso Dossi, Court Painter in Renaissance Ferrara."

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The recordings are grouped first by symposia/theme, followed by a group of more general lectures and presentations. Within each group, the recordings are listed in chronological order.

dao.xlink:title: Scholar Year 1997/1998 and 1998/1999 audio recordings

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The recordings are grouped first by symposia/theme, followed by a group of more general lectures and presentations. Within each group, the recordings are listed in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials comprise audio recordings of events, lectures, and discussions held at the Getty during the scholar years 1997/1998 and 1998/1999. During this time Getty scholars explored the theme of the residential scholar program Representing the Passions and studied the ways in which strong, ungovernable emotions have been represented and classified in the arts throughout the history of the arts and humanities. This theme focused on the social need to name the passions (thus distinguishing them from one another) and to develop gestural and rhetorical conventions and codes in reference to them, while simultaneously noting how the ungovernability of the passions threatens either to break through or to be lost by the cultural conventions and codes that attempt to ritualize and control them. Theorists of human nature, language, and politics have wrestled with the challenge of the ungovernability of the passions since antiquity and the challenge continues to confront contemporary painters, actors, writers, and musicians.

dao.xlink:title: Scholar Year 1997/1998 and 1998/1999: Interpreting El Lissitzky: New Perspectives audio recording

daodesc.p: Scholar Year 1997/1998 and 1998/1999: Interpreting El Lissitzky: New Perspectives audio recording

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials comprise audio recordings of lectures from a 1998 Getty Research Institute conference titled "Interpreting El Lissitzky: New Perspectives." In these lectures an international group of scholars examine works by El Lissitzky, one of the most influential artists of the early 20th-century Russian avant-garde. Scholars discuss his book designs, demonstration spaces, photographs, and the propaganda billboard, in order to assess the importance of underlying threads that hold his diverse career together. The conference was held in conjunction with the Getty's exhibition, "Monuments of the Future": Designs by El Lissitzky, which opened in November, 1998.

did.unittitle: Mapping L.A.: A Global Prototype symposium

dao.xlink:title: Scholar Year 1997/1998 and 1998/1999: Mapping L.A. Symposium audio recordings

daodesc.p: Scholar Year 1997/1998 and 1998/1999: Mapping L.A. Symposium audio recordings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials comprise audio recordings of the 1999 symposium "Mapping L.A.: A Global Prototype," which was designed to spotlight the archives of Southern California and celebrate the publication: "Cultural Inheritance LA: A Directory of Less-Visible Archives and Collections in the Los Angeles Region." The symposium was part of the L.A. as Subject collaboration. The first day of the symposium was by invitation only and had a scholarly and theoretical focus. Day One featured keynote speaker Angela Oh and included a videoconference panel discussion with Prague regarding the Stories Exchange Project. The second day was open to the public and featured professional archivists, curators, and historians who shared information about preserving and displaying collections. Day Two speakers included Janet Fireman, Robert Gottlieb, Ruben Martinez and others.

arrangement.head: Arrangement

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials comprise recordings of events, lectures, and discussions held at the Getty during the scholar year 1999/2000. During this time Getty scholars explored the theme Humanities in Comparative, Historical Perspective. Scholars studied how the humanities had developed as a cultural category in the United States and what work was done (or avoided) by this categorization. They were particularly interested in the relation of the history of art to other fields of humanistic study. How had these fields developed in relation to the arts, and how were contemporary artistic practices being informed by and making contributions to these fields? They were also interested in the connections between the humanities and other areas of culture, including the sciences, popular culture, and religion. How had the identity of the humanities developed in relation and contradistinction to these other areas, and what productive connections could be developed between them? Their approach to these issues was largely comparative and historical. That is, they explored how cultural categories analogous to "humanities" (sciences humaines and Geisteswissenschaften, for example) had developed in diverse contexts around the world and examined the different kinds of cultural work in these categories.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The recordings are grouped first by symposia/theme, followed by a group of more general lectures and presentations. Within each group, the recordings are in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials comprise recordings of events, lectures, and discussions held at the Getty during the scholar year 2000/2001. During this time Getty Scholars explored the theme Reproductions and originals. Of interest during this scholar year were such issues as the often fugitive nature of reproductive media; the ambiguous status of reproductions as "realistic" representations or decontextualized fragments; the use of reproductions in defining intellectual categories and developing object taxonomies; the pedagogical applications of visual archives; asymmetries between direct observation, textual description, and illustration; and the roles of reproductive images in establishing, sustaining, recovering, and replacing cultural memory. Of interest also were questions stemming from any number of relevant subjects, from ekphrasis to conceptual art, from Cassiano Dal Pozzo's Paper Museum to quotation practices by postmodern artists, from tapestry production in the Old Regime to Chinese literati painting and calligraphy in the manner of revered masters. The words used to address subjects such as these led to controversial questions about authenticity and creativity of import to scholars from across the humanities.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: A researcher may request access of recordings available for on-site access only by placing a request through the Getty's Interlibrary Loan program.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials comprise recordings of events, lectures, and discussions held at the Getty during the scholar year 2000/2001. During this time Getty scholars explored the theme Reproductions and Originals. Scholars studied the premise that the use of reproductions by art historians—past and present—is worth looking at more closely.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Due to rights restrictions, some of the online versions of the recordings are available to on-site researchers only. A researcher may request access of specific recordings for in-library use at a local library by placing a request through the Getty's Interlibrary Loan program.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of 33 VHS tapes, 47 KCA60 3/4" U-matic videocassette masters, and a viewing schedule covering the research theme of the Getty Scholar Program for the 1986/1987 year: "Seventeenth Century Dutch Art and Society/Patronage." The symposium on Florentine patronage in the 15th century is included in these tapes, as is the viewing schedule that was issued to the Getty staff on December 8, 1987.

processinfo.head: Processing notes
processinfo.p: Note: All Post-its have been removed from direct contact with the images. Post-its attached to photography for tagging purposes have been removed and attached to the archival sleeve in the same location. Post-its attached to photography with additional information (cropping directions, photograph notes, etc.) have been photocopied and placed with the photograph in the archival folder. Post-its already on archival sleeves have been left as they are, regardless of content.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of photographs taken by Pamela Blackwell, Robert Walker, and other photographers, 1985-2007, for the Getty Scholar Program. The photographs are 35mm or larger 1 1/2" by 2 1/4" negatives, slides, contact sheets, or 8"x10" or 11"x14" oversize photographic prints. The black-and-white photographs of Getty scholars were used to select official scholar portraits. Official black-and-white portraits were also selectively taken of guest scholars, pre-doctoral fellows, post-doctoral fellows, and occassionally research associates. Other photographs document scholar activities including tours, symposia, receptions, and other events. Occasional photographs of program staff are also included.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Except for the photographic essays, which have been listed first, these records are arranged chronologically by year.

If the scholar year has no subheadings or has the subheading "Scholars and fellows," the photographs comprise Getty scholar, visiting scholar, pre-doctoral fellow, post-doctoral fellow, and occassionally research associate portraits. The subheading "Scholar Program people and activities" refers to non-portrait photographs of people and activities of the Scholar Program dating from a particular scholar year.
